boat.name: Pioneer
boat.full_description:
Restored over six years by the Pioneer Sailing Trust, who started the project 1998, Pioneer is now fully fitted out for sail training.

She worked as a sailing fishing vessel off the coasts of the Netherlands and English East Coast from 1864 until 1929 when her first engine was fitted. In 1939 she was decommissioned and became a houseboat at East Mersea, Essex. During the war, 1942, she was towed to the Strood Channel at West Mersea but broke her moorings and sank.

Visit her website for the full story of Pioneer and the Pioneer Sailing Trust.

Read about the East Coast scouts sailing on 'Pioneer' in 2015.
boat.short_description: Built by Peter Harris at Rowhedge in 1864, Pioneer was originally 57 ft. overall length working out of Brightlingsea dredging deep sea oysters. Lengthened by Aldous in 1889, and having a "wet well", she's probably the last remaining UK sailing fishing vessel with one.

builderByBuilder.name: Harris Brothers
builderByBuilder.notes: Harris Brothers boat yard was established by Peter Thomas Harris in 1865 and was later run by his sons Enos and John Thomas Harris. The yard was taken over by Rowhedge Ironworks circa 1915.
